author: Mitchell Neems
title: Pacific Brands narrows full-year loss and flags resumption of dividends | Business News | Business and Finance News | | The
text:
PACIFIC Brands says it expects to start paying dividends again this half but has warned challenging market conditions are likely to continue.
The owner of the Bonds and Sheridan brands has also flagged the possibility it will raise prices to combat the impact of currency headwinds.
For the year to June, Pacific Brands has posted a net loss of $97.7 million — an improvement on the $224.5 million loss a year earlier.
The result was due largely to first-half non-cash impairments on goodwill, brand names and plant and equipment totalling $138.5 million.
Those impairments were driven by a change in the definition of cash generating units, as well as adverse moves in foreign exchange rates.
Before significant items, Pacific Brands delivered a profit of $37.5 million, largely in line with analysts' expectations which had centred on a $37.4 million result.
Revenue from continuing operations rose 5.4 per cent to $789.7 million.
Pacific Brands said two of its of its key brands, Bonds and Sheridan, recorded a lift in full-year sales of 13 per cent and 15 per cent respectively.
The company also said it expected annual earnings before interest and tax from continuing operations — excluding one-off items — to exceed the $64.2 million recorded in the past financial year.
The group declined to pay a final dividend, but said it intended to resume its dividend payments at its first-half results this financial year.
It has a target payout ratio of at least 50 per cent of net profit after tax.
The company said challenging and variable market conditions were likely to continue, but noted that sales for the first 8 weeks of this financial year were 8 per cent higher than they were in that period a year ago.
However, the overall performance of Pacific Brands in the first-half is very dependent on November and December trading.
Pacific Brands added that currency headwinds continued and could impact future earnings, but it had plans in place to reduce the impact through sourcing benefits, mix improvement, cost of doing business reductions and price increases.
"Currency depreciation has continued to be a challenge for the industry as a whole, but we have plans in place to mitigate the dollar impact on margins through a range of cost reduction and pricing measures," chief executive David Bortolussi said.
“We have clear strategic priorities and operational plans in place to deliver profit growth in fiscal 2016.”
Originally published as Pacific Brands eyes dividend restart
